quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: What would be the point of an existence where you don’t create? That’s the whole purpose of the human soul.
quotes.context: His deepest “why” for making games at all—frames RTYI as a life philosophy, not a hobby project.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Making this game is honestly like scaling 50 Everests.
quotes.context: A vivid scope statement that instantly communicates endurance, scale, and the long grind of finishing RTYI.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is what the N64 games could have looked like. You were robbed.
quotes.context: A provocative mission line: RTYI isn’t only nostalgia—it’s a “lost potential” argument about the hardware and the era.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This all runs on real hardware. That’s the whole point.
quotes.context: The project’s central thesis in one sentence—authenticity and engineering discipline over emulator-only spectacle.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support.
quotes.context: A punchy example of the hack’s technical audacity—modern rendering ideas forced onto original-era constraints.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: We’re missing one kilobyte of RAM. This is a quarter of a texture.
quotes.context: Perfect “debug-room” moment that makes N64 limitations tangible and dramatic for non-technical audiences.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I want to stick to the 64 megabyte limit because that’s what they worked with back in the day. Going over that would feel like cheating.
quotes.context: Defines the self-imposed constraint that shapes every asset and system choice—authenticity as an artistic rule.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is guaranteed open source. I want people to be able to maintain this code base after I leave the scene, and I want other people to be able to make hacks off of my engine.
quotes.context: Legacy-minded statement: RTYI as community infrastructure, not just a one-time release.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I think making a game is all about designing a feeling that you want the player to have.
quotes.context: His creative north star—bridges engineering, level design, art direction, and pacing into one human idea.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: The overworld needs to be full of secrets. That is so important. That’s going to make or break the game. Guaranteed.
quotes.context: A clear, high-stakes creative priority that can anchor an “overworld” chapter (and show what quality means to him).

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can rework it; I can sell it on Steam. If they don’t take it down, also great. I get to make my mod.
quotes.context: Turns legal threat into a dramatic fork-in-the-road—external pressure reframed as strategy and survival.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: When I watch the player and it’s painful to watch them, I need to make it easier—and it was very painful to watch her.
quotes.context: A pivotal playtest moment tied to Zeina—shows iteration, empathy, and how their relationship directly affects design decisions.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: We’re going to have a kid in like two months. That’s the due date.
quotes.context: Life-event pivot that raises stakes and reframes time, priorities, and what “finishing the game” means.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: You know what’s the most messed up part about being a famous romaker? People harass me about the release date, and when I say I want time with my family, I’m the bad guy.
quotes.context: A raw midpoint-low moment about entitlement, burnout, and the cost of building in public—especially with family in the frame.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: To me, the anxiety of working on 64 Land is a blur in my memory. I don’t remember that I made that game. It’s like someone else took possession of my body and made it.
quotes.context: Rare vulnerability about past projects and psychological toll—sets stakes for sustainability, obsession, and self-protection.
